revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.2.5)
revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name= Sir Arthur Cavenagh Leveson |image= Arthur Leveson EN0491.JPG |caption= Arthur Leveson as Rear Admiral Commanding HM Australian Fleet |birth_date= {{birth date|1868|01|27|df=yes}} |death_date= {{death date and age|1929|06|26|1868|01|27|df=yes}} |birth_place= [[Kensington]], London, England |death_place= [[Contrexéville]], France |allegiance= United Kingdom |branch= [[Royal Navy]] |serviceyears= 1881–1928 |rank= [[Admiral (Royal Navy)|Admiral]] |unit= |commands= [[China Station]] (1922–25)
[[2nd Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|2nd Battle Squadron]] (1919–20)
[[5th Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|5th Battle Squadron]] (1918–19)
[[Commander Australian Fleet|HM Australian Fleet]] (1917–18)
{{HMS|Indefatigable|1909|6}} (1911–13)
{{HMS|Africa|1905|6}} (1908–19)
{{HMS|King Edward VII||6}} (1905–07) |battles= [[First World War]] * [[Battle of Jutland]] |awards= [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]]
[[Mentioned in Despatches]]
[[Legion of Honour|Officer of the Legion of Honour]] (France)
[[Order of Saint Stanislaus|Order of Saint Stanislaus, 1st Class]] (Russia)
[[Order of the Rising Sun|Order of the Rising Sun, 2nd Class]] (Japan) |laterwork= }} [[Admiral (Royal Navy)|Admiral]] '''Sir Arthur Cavenagh Leveson''' [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath|GCB]] (27 January 1868 – 26 June 1929) was a senior officer in the [[Royal Navy]]. He was the [[Commander Australian Fleet|Rear Admiral Commanding His Majesty's Australian Fleet]] from 9 January 1917 to 3 September 1918 and later Commander in Chief, [[China Station]] from 10 September 1922 to 22 April 1925.Dodd, Chapt. 8 (Part 2) ==Naval career== Born on 27 January 1868 at [[Kensington]], London,{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/documentsonline/details-result.asp?Edoc_Id=7894566|title=RN Officer's Service Records—Image details—Leveson, Arthur Cavenagh|work=DocumentsOnline|publisher=[[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]]|format=fee usually required to view pdf of full original service record|accessdate=3 September 2009}} he attended a private school, and began his naval cadetship aboard the training ship [[HMS Britannia (1860)|HMS ''Britannia'']] on 13 January 1881. He was rated [[midshipman]] on 15 January 1883 and [[sub-lieutenant]] on 17 January 1887 and promoted [[lieutenant]] on 27 July 1887. He was awarded the Beaufort Testimonial and Goodenough Medal in 1888 and qualified in gunnery in 1891. Serving as a Gunnery Lieutenant upon [[HMS Victoria (1887)|HMS ''Victoria'']] in 1893, he survived the sinking of HMS ''Victoria'' on 22 June 1893 after she collided with [[HMS Camperdown (1885)|HMS ''Camperdown'']] near [[Tripoli, Lebanon|Tripoli]], [[Lebanon]] during manoeuvres and quickly sank, taking 358 crew with her, including the commander of the [[British Mediterranean Fleet]], Vice Admiral [[George Tryon|Sir George Tryon]]. Transferred to [[Whale Island, Hampshire|Whale Island]] at the shore establishment [[HMS Excellent (shore establishment)|HMS ''Excellent'']] as a 1st Gunnery Office. He was promoted to [[lieutenant]] on 27 July 1887.{{London Gazette|issue=25875|startpage=6204|supp= |date=16 November 1888|accessdate=28 August 2009}} While as a Brigade Major to the Naval Brigade in London, he participated in the occasion of Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee in 1897, for which he received the [[Queen Victoria Diamond Jubilee Medal]]. Promoted to [[commander]] on 1 January 1899 he became a fellow of the [[Royal Geographical Society]].{{London Gazette|issue=27040|startpage=84|supp= |date=6 January 1899|accessdate=28 August 2009}} Serving as commander under his first commission aboard [[HMS Canopus (1897)|HMS ''Canopus'']] he was promoted to [[Captain (naval)|captain]] on 1 July 1903.{{London Gazette|issue=27572|startpage=4187|supp= |date=3 July 1903|accessdate=28 August 2009}} From August 1903 until February 1905, he served as the Naval Assistant to the Controller of the Navy. While serving as Flag Captain to Admiral [[William May (Royal Navy officer)|Sir William May]], Commander in Chief of the [[British Atlantic Fleet|Atlantic Fleet]], he took part in 1904 in the [[Entente Cordiale]] at Brest and in Paris, for which he received the [[Croix d'Officier of the Legion of Honour]]. He later commanded [[HMS Africa (1905)|HMS ''Africa'']] and [[HMS Indefatigable (1909)|HMS ''Indefatigable'']] and received the [[King George V Coronation Medal|Coronation Medal]] of [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]] in 1911. On 27 September 1912, he was made a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] in the Civil Division in the first batch of naval officers awarded this honour, and was made naval [[aide-de-camp]] to King George V in 1913.{{London Gazette|issue=28648|startpage=7107|supp= |date=27 September 1912|accessdate=28 August 2009}} He was also a commodore (first class) on the staff of Admiral of the Fleet Sir William May, Umpire-in-Chief during the Naval Manoeuvres which took place during July and August 1913. Promoted to [[rear admiral]] on 1 December 1913,{{London Gazette|issue=28780|startpage=9083|supp= |date=9 December 1913|accessdate=28 August 2009}} and Director of Operations Divisions of the Admiralty War Staff on 1 May 1914. After the outbreak of the [[First World War]] in 1914, he was second in command of the [[2nd Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|2nd Battle Squadron]], and was present at the [[Battle of Jutland]] on 31 May 1916, where he was [[mentioned in despatches]], received a Companion of the Order of the Bath in the Military Division,{{London Gazette|issue=29751|startpage=9063|supp=yes|date=15 September 1916|accessdate=28 August 2009}} the [[Order of St. Stanislaus]] (First Class) with swords and the [[Order of the Rising Sun]] (Second Class). He was appointed the [[Commander Australian Fleet|Rear Admiral Commanding HM Australian Fleet]] in January 1917, commander of the [[5th Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|5th Battle Squadron]] in October 1918 and commander of the [[2nd Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|2nd Battle Squadron]] in April 1919. He was appointed [[China Station|Commander in Chief, China Station]] in September 1922. He became the First and Principal Naval aide-de-camp and was awarded the [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] on 3 June 1927.{{London Gazette|issue=33280|startpage=3605|supp=yes|date=31 May 1927|accessdate=28 August 2009}} ==Family== Leveson married, at St. Paul's, [[Valletta, Malta]], on 3 March 1902, Jemima Adeline Beatrice Blackwood, widow of [[Edward Henry Stuart Bligh, 7th Earl of Darnley]], and daughter of Francis James Lindesay Blackwood.{{Cite newspaper |newspaper=The Times |title=Marriages |date=17 March 1902 |page=1 |issue=Issue 36717 }}{{cite web|title=Sitter: Lady Jemima Laveson, formely Countess of Darnley , née Jemima Adeline Beatrice Blackwood (d 1964).|url=http://lafayette.org.uk/bla2068a.html|publisher=Lafayette Negative Archive}} They had one son, Arthur Edmund Leveson (1908–1981), and their eldest granddaughter, Anne Pamela Leveson (born 1946), became Countess of Hopetoun by her marriage in 1968 to the [[Adrian Hope, 4th Marquess of Linlithgow|4th Marquess of Linlithgow]], and in 1988 became Countess De La Warr by her second marriage to [[William Sackville, 11th Earl De La Warr]].{{cite book |title=Burke's Peerage, Baronetage and Knightage |edition=107th |volume=1 |page=1074 |year=2003 |editor-first=Charles |editor-last=Mosley |isbn=978-0971196629 }} Cited in {{cite web |editor-first=Darryl Roger |editor-last=Lundy |title=Anne Pamela Leveson |work=The Peerage |url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p14945.htm#i46849 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160325211106/http://thepeerage.com/p14945.htm#i46849 |archivedate=25 March 2016 |df=dmy }} Admiral Sir Arthur Leveson died on 26 June 1929 at [[Contrexéville]], France.{{cite book |title=Burke's Peerage, Baronetage and Knightage |edition=107th |volume=1 |page=1074 |year=2003 |editor-first=Charles |editor-last=Mosley |isbn=978-0971196629 }} Cited in {{cite web |editor-first=Darryl Roger |editor-last=Lundy |title=Admiral Sir Arthur Cavenagh Leveson |work=The Peerage |url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p7081.htm#i70810 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403005943/http://thepeerage.com/p7081.htm#i70810 |archivedate=3 April 2016 |accessdate=28 August 2009 |df=dmy }} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== *Dodd, Francis (1917). ''Admirals of the British Navy (1917–1918) – Part 2'', London, Country Life Ltd. [https://archive.org/stream/admiralsofbritis00dodduoft#page/n5/mode/2up online library] *[http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/1620296?searchTerm=Arthur+Cavenagh+Leveson The Argus (Melbourne, Vic) – Friday 25 May 1917. p6.] {{S-start}} {{S-mil}} {{Succession box| title={{nowrap|[[Commander Australian Fleet|Rear Admiral Commanding HM Australian Fleet]]}}| before= [[William Christopher Pakenham|Sir William Pakenham]]| after= [[Lionel Halsey|Sir Lionel Halsey]]| years=1917–1918| }} |- {{Succession box| title=[[China Station|Commander-in-Chief, China Station]] | before=[[Alexander Ludovic Duff|Sir Alexander Duff]] | after=[[Allan Everett (Royal Navy officer)|Sir Allan Everett]] | years=1922–1924}} |- {{S-hon}} {{S-bef| before=[[Montague Browning|Sir Montague Browning]]}} {{S-ttl| title=[[List of First and Principal Naval Aides-de-Camp|First and Principal Naval Aide-de-Camp]] | years=1926–1928}} {{S-aft| after=[[Richard Phillimore|Sir Richard Phillimore]]}} {{S-end}} {{Fleet Commander of the Royal Australian Navy|state=collapsed}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Leveson}} [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1929 deaths]] [[Category:Knights Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:People from Kensington]] [[Category:Royal Navy admirals of World War I]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Geographical Society]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Rising Sun]]
